body: LGTM other than the minor comments.
LGTM other than the missing header.

Updated. Using the new AvroHdfsTimePartitionedWriter class written by Sahil, and discarded the original AvroHdfsTimePartitionDataWriter class.
All other comments fixed.
Tested in standalone mode.

Looks good in general. About point 1, we could report the total counts for each metric (available in everything but Gauges I think). Other than that, I have the impression Hadoop counters have the expectation of additivity
I screwed up a comment earlier, but I was saying, the HadoopCounterReporter could report the getCount method for each metric type.
@liyinan926 @ibuenros @sahilTakiar  Please let me know if you have more comments.
LGTM. We will finalize ContextAwareReporter API in a future PR.
@zliu41, can you squash all commits for addressing review comments into a single one?
I use https://github.com/jnothman/git-squash to squash commits, pretty handy command line tool to easily squash commits.
@liyinan926 @sahilTakiar Done. All the revisions are combined into the last commit (57d2b17).
LGTM. @narasimhareddyv, can you take a look? Thanks!
@sahilTakiar, can you also take a look at this pull request? This will break the purger code due to the API change and renaming of some classes.

Updated after a discussion with @chavdar. We will still keep the current API, but marking the input parameter `reuse` of `readRecord` as `@Deprecated` and making it clear in the Javadoc. When `Task` calls this method, it will pass in a `null`, which essentially force a new object to be created.
@sahilTakiar, please update the tracking purger once I merge this on.

Nice 2 level bin-packing. 

Is minimizing number of small file a goal or non-goal here? 

For the reduction of per partition files to be effective, after first level bin-packing (or second level to be better),  we need to create one work unit unifying the initial per topic/partition work units from a single WorkUnitGroup , where all the per topic/partition work units from that group are from the same topics. Otherwise, writer will create at least a file per work unit (per topic per partition) without unification, unless the writer behavior has changed.  

On the other hand, as we will have hourly compaction in place to merge small files into bigger ones, minimizing the number of small files will not be as critical as when we only have once in a day daily compaction (i.e. 24x small file # reduction).

@lqiao Minimizing small files is not a critical goal, but since the 2-level approach should significantly reduce the number of small files without any noticeable impact on workunit skew (as long as number of groups > 3\* number of mappers, bin packing will do a good job), I think we should still do it.

After first-level, each group (containing partitions of the same topic) will be assigned to a single multiWorkUnit (KafkaSource line 155).

Since a topic usually has 10 to 100+ partitions and a mapper can usually be assigned at least 5 partitions, this should reduce the number of files by 5x or more. In my random tests the skew is never more than 3%.

Updated (3a9b071).
- For bin packing, using priority queue instead of linear scan
- Removed class WorkUnitGroup and WorkUnitWithEstSize, now using MultiWorkUnit with a property "estimated.data.size".
- Other comments also addressed.
Not done on the review yet. Will continue tomorrow.
@ibuenros, can you take a look at this pull request?
Currently no, but the next version will support tags.
Given the lack of tags, would it make sense to add the tags to the names of the metrics?
The tags will be included if the `MetricContext` the reporter is associated to is configure to `reportFullyQualifiedNames`.
Ok, this looks good to me then.
Sorry but I just realized I missed some comments on the schema and just added them back.
@liyinan926 can you look at updated version?
LGTM other than a few minor comments.
Fixed last comments. Is this ready to merge?
Closed for now since further change is needed based on the behavior of the new API.

As per conversation with Chavdar. I have removed the `increment(Object record)` from the `Watermark` interface. It is now up to the `Extractor` class to update the `Watermark`. I have also removed the Jackson based serialization of the `Watermark` class and have just added `toJson` and `initFromJson` methods to the `Watermark` interface. Jackson is not that efficient, and can be messy to deal with, so its best use a simpler serialization approach.

So now the expected e2e flow is as follows:

1: The `Source` class creates a series of `WorkUnit`s, each `WorkUnit` contains a `WatermarkInterval`. The `WatermarkInterval` contains a low watermark, expected high watermark, and an actual high watermark. It is possible that a `WorkUnit` is not always able to pull data from its low watermark, to its high watermark. Take Camus for example, where map tasks only pull data for a (topic, partition) for "x" amount of time, and then move on to the next (topic, partition).

2: Each `WorkUnit` is then serialized into a SequenceFile

3: Each map task reads a series of `WorkUnit`s from this sequence file, and de-serializes them. It then executes these `WorkUnit`s.

4: The `Extractor` class is responsible for maintaining the following invariant. After each call to `readRecord()` the `Watermark` returned by `getCurrentHighWatermark` should cover all records up to and including the last record returned by `readRecord()`. This method may be called multiple times in order to report the % completion of the `WorkUnit`.

The following questions are still open:

1: I have added a new method to `Extractor` which is causing a lot of other classes to break

2: In order to avoid another state-store migration, I have added a hack to serialize the WatermarkInterval class. Should be discuss migrating away from SequenceFile formats?

Wants to share some of my thoughts on the `Watermark` and `WatermarkInterval` classes:
1. `Watermark` should be generic with a type parameter and a method `public T getValue()`. 
2. `WatermarkInterval` should be immutable and only contain two things, the low and high `Watermark`s. Then it's essentially a `PairWritable`.
3. The logic of maintaining a `currentWatermark` and manipulating it should be left to the extractors. The runtime is only responsible for serialization/deserialization of the interval.
4. `Watermark` does not need to extend `Copyable` given the above three points.

If `Watermark` is generic, then in addition to a `MyWatermark` class, I also need another class `MyWatermarkValueType` and do
`public class MyWatermark implements Watermark<MyWatermarkValueType>`, which doesn't seem necessary. Why not put those values directly in `MyWatermark`?

It seems the `getX` method can be implemented in each individual Watermark class if needed, e.g., `IntWatermark.getInt()`, `LongWatermark.getLong()`, `PairLongWatermark.getFirst()`, `PairLongWatermark.getSecond()` etc.

I don't quite understand your point. Regardless of whether `Watermark` is generic or not, you still need to put some type of value into your `MyWatermark` class. With generic, the only additional thing you need to do is to specify explicitly what is the type of that value. The benefits are you allow the compiler to enforce type checking, which is always better than using `Object`.

It's good to have a common method like `getValue` so it is able to get the value of a `Watermark` as long as it has access to the interface. If every implementation classes implement their own way of getting the value of a `Watermark`, then the code that needs the value needs to know the specific implementation class and very likely need to do a casting before it is able to call that method.

@liyinan926 for points 2 and 3. I like the idea of having a `WatermarkInterval` only containing two `Watermark`s, a low and a high `Watermark`. However, I think it is still important that the runtime high watermark still get serialized along with the `WorkUnitState`. The source class should have access to the `WorkUnitState`s of the previous run, along with some way to access the low, expected high, and actual high watermark.

Perhaps, the `WorkUnit` can have a `WatermarkInterval` that contains the low and expected high `Watermark`, and the `WorkUnitState` can have the actual high `Watermark`. Thoughts?

@sahilTakiar, yeah, I think that's a good solution. So basically the source/extractor gives the `WorkUnitState` a reference to the `actualHighWatermark`, and increments that as records get extracted. Upon completion of the task, the `actualHighWatermark` and the `WatermarkInterval` get serialized as part of the `WorkunitState`. When serializing the `actualHighWatermark`, the `WorkUnitState` simply calls the `toJson` method. In addition, the `WatermarkInterval` that is immutable should be owned by the `WorkUnit` inside the `WorkUnitState`, whereas the `actualHighWatermark` should be owned by the `WorkUnitState`.

Updated. The `Watermark` interface now contains a `fromJson(JsonElement json)` and a `JsonElement toJson()` method.

I removed the new method from the `Extractor` interface so we don't break all the dependent classes, the `WorkUnitState.setHighWatermark(Watermark)` method is now responsible for setting the runtime high watermark. This method must be called during the `Extractor` initialization so that the `WorkUnitState` can properly report the progress of the `Watermark`.

I also changed `WatermarkInterval` to contain just two `Watermarks`, and now the `WorkUnit` serializes a `WatermarkInterval`, and the `WorkUnitState` just serializes a single high `Watermark`.

@liyinan926 I am not entirely sure I understand why / how to make the `Watermark` generic. The `Watermark` interface may contain a variety of data structures used to track the progress of a `WorkUnitState` - e.g. maps, arrays, lists, etc. The only requirement is that all these data structures can be converted into a `JsonElement`, and that it is possible to do comparisons.

Hey, so I think the `Watermark` interface could be used in a couple different ways, depending on the source:
- For MySQL, each table has a single `Date` value inside its `Watermark` interface
- For SFTP, the `Watermark` interface contains a list of files that have already been pulled
- For Kafka, the `Watermark` contains a `Map` of from a Kafka (topic, partition) pair to some offset

For all the above use cases I think have a `getValue()` function would be good, for MySQL you would have `public class MySQL implements Watermark<Long>` and the method `public Long getValue()`.

However, if we take that approach then we add a restriction any class that implements the `Watermark` interface. The restriction is that the `Watermark` but be represented entirely by one data structure. While I can't think of any Source that would need multiple data structures to represent its `Watermark`, but it may entirely be possible.

Also, I think the `toJson()` method is already doing what the `getValue()` method would do. The `toJson()` method allows you to return the value of the `Watermark` in JSON format.
Let's discuss this in person. I don't understand why we need getValue(). The Watermark should be the watermark implementation. We already have a container for watermarks -- the workunit.

Updated e9acd2ffa5b906ae8780a4856671d2626d8f44d0. Major changes are:
1. The way cancellation is handled. `AbstractJobLauncher` now has a default implementation of `cancelJob` that simply sets the flag `cancellationRequested` (which is `volatile boolean`), which indicates that cancellation is requested. Then the method will `wait` (with timeout) on a object named `cancellationLock` on which `notify` will be called once the cancellation is successfully executed. No explicit synchronization is needed for `cancellationRequested` since it is `volatile boolean`. The responsibility of executing the cancellation is done in the `runWorkUnits` method of the implementation classes of `JobLauncher`. In `MRJobLauncher`, `runWorkUnits` will periodically check if the flag `cancellationRequested` is set, and will kill the Hadoop job if it is. In `LocalJobLauncher`, `runWorkUnits` will also periodically check if the flag `cancellationRequested` is set, and will drain the `CountDownLatch` if it is.
2. Added a new class `JobContext` that contains all context information of a job. This simplifies `AbstractJobLauncher`.

@chavdar I still have some questions, so maybe we can sync up. Primarily, I realized that I will also have to change the `calculatePercentCompletion` method to take two `JsonElement`s instead of `Watermark`s, since this method will get called in the in the map task.

Which seems a little odd from a usability perspective, ideally the user should not need to worry about the fact that `Watermark` is getting serialized.
Please ignore the last update. I am working on a better way of handling cancellation.
